properties.Description: The Dakota Dunes Hotel will boast 155 rooms and will join the existing Dakota Dunes Casino and world-class Golf Course. An on-site full-service spa is set to open in 2021.

Lakeside Golf Resort will become the longest 9 hole golf course in Saskatchewan. The course will also house a stunning events centre complete wedding facilities, sports bar, gym, members change room, sauna, and outdoor pool.
Toronto-based KingSett Capital is investing $80 Million to redevelop the Midtown Plaza in downtown Saskatoon. The new food court was completed in summer 2019.

Wanuskewin Heritage Park is seeking UNESCO World Heritage designation to become the first World Heritage site in Saskatchewan. To do so Wanuskewin is expanding their Interpretive Centre and adding a bison herd to their park.

Morguard Real Estate Investment Trust invested $43 Million into the Centre Mall to modernize the interior and exterior,  develop the new Cineplex pad and refit the former Target space to welcome new retailers.
A 10-story apartment tower that will feature 68 rental units, and 20,000 square feet of retail space on the first two floors. Built by Baydo Development.
A 17-story condo developed by Victory Major Development Corp. and Urban Capital Property Group featuring 112 units, 3.5 levels of underground parking and 2 floors of retail/commercial space.
A 7-story condo tower developed by Meridian Developments will feature 41 units and underground parking. Units will be priced between $500,000 to $1 Million.

North Prairie Developments is designing a 12-storey, 171-unit condo building at the corner of Clarence Avenue and College Drive, south of University Bridge. Condos are expected to sell for $300,000 - $800,000 and construction set to start in 2021.
Baydo Development Corp is planning to build two 23-storey towers containing 364 rental units and four levels of underground parking.

The Saskatoon Public Library will be building a new 149,000-square-foot library in downtown Saskatoon. On March 20, 2020 the Board purchased a $9 Million plot of land and will begin the design stage immediately.

Recovery Park will be a one-stop recycling and waste facility.  It will be located at the Saskatoon landfill to provide waste diversion opportunities for recyclables, hazardous waste, food and yard waste, construction waste and others.

Major renovations to the Sid Buckwold Bridge began in Spring 2019 and is being conducted in two phases. The first phase on the West side of the bridge was completed in 2019. Phase two will begin in April 2020. The rehabilitation will replace the bridge deck and asphalt, introduce a new drainage system, and strengthen the piers.

The Gordie Howe Sports Complex renovation is the largest sports project in Saskatoon's history. The project will include a new dual track and field/speed skating oval facility, 90,000-square foot multi-purpose indoor athletic performance and training centre, Saskatoon Sports Hall of Fame, Nordic cross-country ski tracks, multi-sport operations centre for baseball, track and field, cross-country skiing and speed skating, plus a multi-sport plaza and ticket centre.

Nutrien Tower is part of a $300 Million mega project at River Landing which also includes a 20-storey condominium, 15-storey hotel, and 13-storey office tower. It will be the tallest building in Saskatchewan standing 88 metres tall and featuring 18-storeys.

The Delta Bessborough is renovating its entire facility and repositioning itself to a higher Marriott tier brand called Autograph. The Autograph Collection is a group of 135 independent hotels owned by Marriott described as unique boutique hotels chosen based on the connection to the city, its history, and design. There are five Canadian Autograph Collection hotels, including the Hotel Saskatchewan in Regina.
The Shakespeare on the Saskatchewan site will undergo construction to build a new permanent amphitheatre, three seasonal pavilions for the box office/gift shop, dressing rooms and a concession/bar.

Warman will expand and upgrade the city’s sewage treatment lagoon will increase the facility’s wastewater treatment capacity. The upgrades are needed in order to accommodate future community growth and improve the overall effluent discharge quality to meet Environment Canada’s regulations.
The expansion will include a second ice surface,  six dressing rooms, a storage room, a dressing room for a Junior A calibre hockey team or equivalent, an office space and trainer’s room.
The new K-12 school in Rosthern will replace Rosthern Elementary School, built in 1968, and Rosthern High School, built in 1961. The school will be able to accommodate 450 students.
The Provincial Government has yet to give the “official” approval for the project; however, municipalities surrounding Rosthern have been fundraising for their portion ($7M).

The City of Saskatoon is searching for a potential site for the combined arena and convention centre in downtown Saskatoon. The arena will also be part of an entertainment district that will evolve around the facility.

Construction of the Multi-purpose Facility will be broken into multiple phases and the it will feature three ice sheets, leisure ice, an indoor field turf, dressing rooms, a climbing wall, indoor playground, spectator seating, multipurpose rooms, and offices.  The first phase of the proposed building is estimated to cost between $12 to $13 million.
This freeway is expected to be a four-lane, 55-kilometre stretch of divided highway that begins at Highway 11 south of Saskatoon and connects with Highway 7 west of the city.
Roadway construction on Highway 5 includes adding passing lanes, widening shoulders, resurfacing, and intersection re-alignment at the St. Denis access.

properties.Project Name: Martensville Wastewater Treatment & Water Distribution Upgrades
properties.Description: Martensville is upgrading its existing lagoons, building a new gravity conveyance system to connect to the City of Saskatoon’s sanitary sewer system, and upgrading the existing sewage lift station. In addition, the City will also upgrade the water supply reservoir and pumping stations and install a new water main that will connect to Saskatoon’s drinking water supply system.
